text: The Rabbit and the Hare
Once upon a time, there were two brothers, Rabbit and Hare.
"I have a long tail," said Rabbit.
"I have a magic tail," said Hare.
One day, Rabbit said, "I'm going far away to play."
"Be careful, brother Rabbit," said Hare.
Rabbit came to a cave.
Someone was sleeping inside.
"Wake up!" said Rabbit, but no one answered.
"I'll make you wake up!" said Rabbit, and he shot his bow and arrow.
A big bear came out of the cave.
"Roar! who shot me in the nose!" asked Bear.
"I did! Ha, ha, ha!" answered Rabbit.
"Little bunny, I'm going to eat you!" roared Bear.
Bear grabbed Rabbit.
"Brother Hare, brother Harel Help me!" cried Rabbit.
Hare appeared.
"Bear, let him gol" he yelled.
"Nol I'm going to eat himl" said Bear.
"Then I'll grow bigger than you!" yelled Hare.
So Hare grew bigger than Bear.
"I'll leave your brother alone!" said Bear, and he ran away.
"Don't be bad, brother Rabbit," said Hare.
"Sure, sure," said Rabbit.
The next day, Rabbit came to a cliff.
A hungry vulture saw Rabbit.
"Ha, ha! Look at the little bunny!" said Vulture.
"Hey, little bunny!" called Vulture.
"I'm not a little bunny!" yelled Rabbit.
"You can't climb up here, little bunny!" said Vulture.
"Yes, I can!" said Rabbit.
"No, you can't!" said Vulture.
"I'll come up and get you!" said Rabbit.
"Then come up and get me, little bunny!" said Vulture.
Rabbit climbed up the cliff.
'Ha, ha, ha!' laughed Vulture.
Vulture was very hungry, so he grabbed Rabbit.
"I'm going to eat you!" he said.
"Brother Hare, brother Harel Help me!" cried Rabbit.
Hare appeared.
"Vulture, let him go!" he yelled.
"No, I'm going to eat him!" said Vulture.
"Then I 'II teach you a lesson!" yelled Hare.
Hare grabbed Vulture and beat him against the ground.
'Ack, help me!" cried Vulture, and he flew away.
"Thank you, brother Hare.
You saved my life!'' said Rabbit.
"Oh, brother Rabbit! Don't be so bad!" said Hare.
"Next time, I won't help you."
"Sure, sure," said Rabbit.
The next day, Rabbit saw three wolves.
Their tails were tied together.
They were playing a game.
"May I play with you?" asked Rabbit.
"No, you can't!" said the first wolf.
"My tail is long and strong," said Rabbit.
The second wolf looked at him.
'Are you sure, brother Rabbit?" said the wolf.
"Sure!'' said Rabbit.
So Rabbit joined in the game.
He pulled and pulled.
"Stop, Rabbitt!
You'll lose your tail!" cried the third wolf.
"No, I'm going to win!" cried Rabbit.
The wolves pulled and pulled.
Rabbit's tail ripped.
"Oh, no!" cried the wolves.
"Where is my long tail?" cried Rabbit.
"Brother Hare, brother Hare! Help me!"
Help me!"
The second wolf turned into Hare.
"What in the world?" cried the other wolves.
"Brother Rabbit, I warned you," said Hare.
"I'm sorry, brother Hare," cried Rabbit.
But Hare loved his brother and felt sorry for him.
"I'll make my tail short, too," said Hare .
"I like our short tails!" said Rabbit.
"You look great, little rabbits!" said the wolves.

After that, they were happy together,
and to this day, rabbits still have short tails.
